an9.3:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Cālikā, on the Cālikā mountain.
an9.3:1.2: Now, at that time Venerable Meghiya was the Buddha’s attendant.
an9.3:1.3: Then Venerable Meghiya went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
an9.3:1.4: “Sir, I’d like to enter Jantu village for alms.”
an9.3:2.1: Then Meghiya robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Jantu village for alms.
an9.3:2.2: After the meal, on his return from almsround in Jantu village, he went to the shore of Kimikālā river.
an9.3:2.3: As he was going for a walk along the shore of the river he saw a lovely and delightful mango grove.
an9.3:2.5: “Oh, this mango grove is lovely and delightful! This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.
an9.3:2.6: If the Buddha allows me, I’ll come back to this mango grove to meditate.”
an9.3:3.1: Then Venerable Meghiya went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding,
an9.3:4.8: “If the Buddha allows me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
an9.3:4.9: “We’re alone, Meghiya. Wait until another mendicant comes.”
an9.3:5.1: For a second time Meghiya said to the Buddha,
an9.3:5.2: “Sir, the Buddha has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
an9.3:5.4: If you allow me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
an9.3:5.5: “We’re alone, Meghiya. Wait until another mendicant comes.”
an9.3:6.1: For a third time Meghiya said to the Buddha,
an9.3:6.2: “Sir, the Buddha has nothing more to do, and nothing that needs improvement.
an9.3:6.4: If you allow me, I’ll go back to that mango grove to meditate.”
an9.3:6.5: “Meghiya, since you speak of striving in meditation, what can I say?
an9.3:6.6: Please, Meghiya, go at your convenience.”
an9.3:7.1: Then Meghiya got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he went to that mango grove, and, having plunged deep into it, sat at the root of a certain tree for the day’s meditation.
an9.3:7.2: But while Meghiya was meditating in that mango grove he was beset mostly by three kinds of bad, unskillful thoughts, namely,
an9.3:7.6: I’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith,
an9.3:7.7: but I’m still harassed by these three kinds of bad, unskillful thoughts:
an9.3:8.1: Then Venerable Meghiya went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
an9.3:10.1: “Meghiya, when the heart’s release is not ripe, five things help it ripen.
an9.3:10.3: Firstly, a mendicant has good friends, companions, and associates.
an9.3:11.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an9.3:12.1: Furthermore, a mendicant gets to take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart, when they want, without trouble or difficulty. That is, talk about fewness of wishes, contentment, seclusion, aloofness, arousing energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom.
an9.3:13.1: Furthermore, a mendicant lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They are strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
an9.3:14.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
an9.3:14.2: This is the fifth thing that, when the heart’s release is not ripe, helps it ripen.
an9.3:15.1: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to
an9.3:16.1: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to
an9.3:16.2: take part in talk about self-effacement that helps open the heart …
an9.3:17.1: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be energetic …
an9.3:18.1: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to be wise …
an9.3:19.1: But then, a mendicant grounded on these five things should develop four further things.
an9.3:19.2: They should develop the perception of ugliness to give up greed, love to give up hate, mindfulness of breathing to cut off thinking, and perception of impermanence to uproot the conceit ‘I am’.
an9.3:19.3: When you perceive impermanence, the perception of not-self becomes stabilized.
an9.3:19.4: Perceiving not-self, you uproot the conceit ‘I am’ and attain extinguishment in this very life.”
